One potential out-of-the-box solution for balancing nationism and nationalism in India could be the development of a decentralized language policy, where decisions regarding language use and promotion are made at the regional level rather than at the national level. This could involve empowering local language experts, community leaders, and educators to develop and implement language policies that are tailored to the specific linguistic and cultural needs of their region.

Such a decentralized approach could help to mitigate some of the tensions between nationism and nationalism by allowing for more nuanced and context-specific language policies that better reflect the diverse linguistic and cultural landscape of India. It could also help to promote greater linguistic and cultural diversity by allowing for the preservation and promotion of minority languages and cultures.

To ensure that these policies are effective and sustainable, it would be necessary to provide adequate resources and support to local communities and language experts. This could involve funding for language revitalization programs, training for language teachers and educators, and support for the development of language materials and resources.

While such a decentralized approach would require significant political will and coordination, it could ultimately lead to a more inclusive and sustainable language policy that better reflects the diverse linguistic and cultural landscape of India.
